sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: The man and info pages of CVS are fairly good but I'm going to list a basic set of commands which all editors will use on an almost daily basis. Note that quite a few things can be set in your local ~/.cvsrc file. For example, I have in there: cvs -z9 diff -u This means that all options use the highest level of compression (I'm on a dial-up link, if you're on broadband it's probably not needed to do this. It does entail a slightly higher processing time for both your machine and shadowfax so think before using it) and says that I always want the cvs diff command to use unified diff format (which all e-mailed submissions (i.e. by those without write CVS access) to blfs-dev should use as they're much easier to read. There are many more options available, you can usually find them by doing cvs --help command. You can also get a basic list of CVS commands by simply doing cvs --help-commands. Having said all of this, let's get on with the commands!.
Some commands have two forms, the long and the short. I'll list both in the description.

sect2.title: cvs checkout/co
sect2.para: cvs checkout or cvs co. This command is used to pull a CVS tree such as LFS/BOOK (the LFS book) or BLFS (the BLFS book) from the server. You should only need to do this once. If we mess around with the directory structure (as sometimes is necessary), you may occasionally need to delete your local sandbox and re-check it out. If this is going to be needed, it will usually be because the Editor will have made a large change and it'll be announced at least on the blfs-book list.

sect2.title: cvs add
sect2.para: cvs add. When you are creating a new file, you need to tell the CVS server about it. This does that. Note that the file won't appear in the repository until you do a cvs commit (see below).

sect2.title: cvs delete/remove
sect2.para: cvs delete or cvs remove. This does what it says! Note that you have to have deleted the file locally before you can run this. Again, the file will not be deleted from the server until you do a cvs commit.

sect2.title: cvs update/up
sect2.para: cvs update or cvs up. This command syncs your local sandbox with the server. If you have made local changes, it'll try and merge any changes on the server with your changes on your machine. You should always do a manual cvs update before trying to commit changes in order to check that everything is alright and ready to go (although when you do a cvs commit, it will warn you if there is a problem).

sect2.title: cvs commit/ci
sect2.para: cvs commit or cvs ci. This command recursively sends your changes to the CVS server. It will commit changed files, added files and deleted files. The -m option can be used to pass a log message to the command. If you don't specify a -m "MESSAGE", then it will open vi (you may be able to override this using the $EDITOR variable but I've never tried it). Please don't use empty log messages (see later in this document on the policy which governs them).

sect2.title: cvs diff
sect2.para: cvs diff. This is useful for two different purposes. Firstly, those without write access to the BLFS CVS server can use it to generate patches to send to blfs-dev. To do this, simply edit the files in your local sandbox then run cvs diff -u > FILE.patch from the root of your BLFS directory. You can then attach this file to a message to blfs-dev where someone with editing rights will pick it up and apply it to the book. The second use is to find out what has changed between two revisions using: cvs diff -u -r revision1 -r revision2 FILENAME. For example: cvs diff -u -r 1.68 -r 1.69 index.xml will output a unified diff showing the changes between revisions 1.68 and 1.69 of index.xml. Remember that when using cvs diff, you nearly always want to output a unified diff and so either use the -u switch or add it to your ~/.cvsrc

sect2.title: Moving files
sect2.para: Moving files: One of the (many?) complaints against cvs is that it has no concept of 1) moving files or 2) versioning directories. If you need to move a file, it's generally better to do it on the server manually. If this is needed, please contact me and I'll do it. This is simply because then if something goes wrong, it's me who takes the fall instead of anyone else!
